content:
First let me give some context. I'm coding an application, and I'm trying to interpret within category theory. Thus, I've started by assuming that the programming code was in the category of sets, with types as sets, and programming functions as mathematical functions in set-theory.

From that, I've coded a free monad D:Set→SetD:\textbf{Set}\to \textbf{Set}D:Set→Set. Given a type XXX, an element of DXDXDX is an expression tree where the leafs have values of type XXX.

In my code, I have an special type called PPP, which represents primitives. Given a type (set) AAA, I wanted to assign a function θA:A→DP\theta_A: A \to D PθA​:A→DP, i.e. a function that receives a value of type AAA and constructs an expression formed by primitives. After some discussion, some people pointed out that the whole thing could be seen as the slice category Kleisli(D)/P\text{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P. Indeed, after inspection, they were right, and this interpretation fits nicely (I wanted the composition to work like it does in the Kleisli category).

Here is my new conundrum. I now want to use my monad DDD to construct expression trees where the leafs have "type" Kleisli(D)/P\text{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P, but Kleisli(D)/P\text{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P is a category not a set. Hence, I can't just interpret it as a type. I was wondering if there is a way to interpret this category in programming. My first idea was to somehow represent Kleisli(D)/P\text{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P as a set or perhaps as a subcategory within the category of sets. I thought of Yoneda lemma (which I am frankly still in the process of fully understanding).

I have a few thoughts/questions for you, as I'm trying to understand what you want to do:

  1. D:Set→SetD: \mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Set}D:Set→Set is a functor, right? I think you're saying it sends a set XXX to the set DXDXDX of all expression trees we can form (using some operators) where all the leaves are elements of XXX. If f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y is a function, I'm wondering what Df:DX→DYDf: DX \to DYDf:DX→DY is. Is this a function that takes in an expression tree, and then swaps out any occurrence of x∈Xx \in Xx∈X with f(x)∈Yf(x) \in Yf(x)∈Y?
  2. I think one idea you are describing is that a function θA:A→DP\theta_A: A \to DPθA​:A→DP tells us how to "build" any element a∈Aa \in Aa∈A using a corresponding expression tree θA(a)\theta_A(a)θA​(a) which describes how to use "primitives" (elements of PPP) to make aaa. That seems really cool!

1. I'm trying to understand your last paragraph. If each function θA:A→DP\theta_A: A \to DPθA​:A→DP is like a collection of recipes for building elements of aaa (and these functions are objects of Kleisli(D)/P\mathrm{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P), then I guess that you are talking about sticking together different collections of recipes to make a fancier collection of recipes (with the "sticking together" process described by some new expression tree)?

This starts to remind me of composition in an operad, which looks like this:
composition in an operad

We could imagine the "wires" coming down the page as the different ingredients we need to build something, and each triangle as a process that uses a given recipe to build something new from these ingredients. (The image is from "Entropy and diversity" by Leinster).

I'm not sure how closely this relates to what you want to do.
For 1., the answer is that DfDfDf is the function that applies fff to each leaf of DXDXDX, turning it into a DYDYDY.
About 3., yeah, it does sounds like operads. But I never quite understood operads and how to use them in programming.
Thus I just went another route. I ended up with the idea of the free monad DDD.

Thanks for clarifying!

I still don't think I quite understand what you want to do. Is a tree where the leaves are objects from Kleisli(D)/P\mathrm{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P the sort of thing you are looking for?

Yes. For example, in DPDPDP I have p1+p2+p3p1 + p2 + p3p1+p2+p3. Which is an expression that says "draw p1p1p1 then p2p2p2 then p3p3p3". I want to have (a∈A,θA)+(b∈B,θB)+(c∈C,θC)(a \in A,\theta_A) + (b \in B,\theta_B) + (c \in C, \theta_C)(a∈A,θA​)+(b∈B,θB​)+(c∈C,θC​).
Which is an expression constructed using DDD, but applying to the object in the slice category.

Note that this expression can be translated into DPDPDP by applying θ\thetaθ, e.g. θA(a)+θB(b)+θC(c)\theta_A(a) + \theta_B(b) + \theta_C(c)θA​(a)+θB​(b)+θC​(c) gives me an expression of expressions i.e. DDPDDPDDP. Since DDD is a monad, I can simply use μ\muμ, thus, μ(θA(a)+θB(b)+θC(c))\mu (\theta_A(a) + \theta_B(b) + \theta_C(c))μ(θA​(a)+θB​(b)+θC​(c)) returns a DPDPDP.
This interests me because it means I can construct complex expressions in DPDPDP using the "encapsulations".
Makes sense?
This has be clumsly coded, but it works... I'm now trying to find a categorical justification

David Egolf said:

Thanks for clarifying!

I still don't think I quite understand what you want to do. Is a tree where the leaves are objects from Kleisli(D)/P\mathrm{Kleisli}(D)/PKleisli(D)/P the sort of thing you are looking for?

Perhaps my example clarified that the leafs have "types"that are objects in Kleisi(D)/P\text{Kleisi(D)}/PKleisi(D)/P, they are not directly the objects.

I guess the idea is similar to saying that I want to use DMonoidD \text{Monoid}DMonoid which should mean that I want to construct a tree where each leave is a monoid, but each monoid can be distinct (e.g. one can be a list of strings, the other can be the integers using sum, and so on).

Davi Sales Barreira said:

Yes. For example, in DPDPDP I have p1+p2+p3p1 + p2 + p3p1+p2+p3. Which is an expression that says "draw p1p1p1 then p2p2p2 then p3p3p3". I want to have (a∈A,θA)+(b∈B,θB)+(c∈C,θC)(a \in A,\theta_A) + (b \in B,\theta_B) + (c \in C, \theta_C)(a∈A,θA​)+(b∈B,θB​)+(c∈C,θC​).

I'm still working on reading the rest of what you said, but these tuples remind me a lot of the "category of elements" construction. If we have a "forgetful" functor U:Kleisli(D)/P→SetU: \mathrm{Kleisli}(D)/P \to \mathsf{Set}U:Kleisli(D)/P→Set that sends θA:A→DP\theta_A: A \to DPθA​:A→DP to just AAA, then an object in the category of elements for UUU is a tuple (θA,a)(\theta_A, a)(θA​,a), where a∈U(θA)=Aa \in U(\theta_A) = Aa∈U(θA​)=A.

Here's the definition, for convenience (from "Category theory in context"):
category of elements

If I understand what you are saying, you want to construct trees where the leaves are tuples of this kind. (These trees encode expressions combining these tuples). If so, I think you are looking for trees having leaves that are objects in the category of elements of U:Kleisli(D)/P→SetU: \mathrm{Kleisli}(D)/P \to \mathsf{Set}U:Kleisli(D)/P→Set.
Hmm, I'm not sure. I'll have to think about it.
